content.question: In a large study designed to compare the risk of cardiovascular disease <math alttext="C V D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>CVD</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> between smokers and nonsmokers, random samples from each group were selected. The sample proportion of people with <math alttext="C V D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CVD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was calculated for each group, and a 95 percent confidence interval for the difference (smoker minus nonsmoker) was given as <math alttext="negative 0.01 comma 0.04" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.01</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>0.04</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is the best interpretation of the interval?

choices.label: We are 95% confident that the difference in proportions for smokers and nonsmokers with <math alttext="C V D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CVD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the sample is between <math alttext="negative 0.01" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and 0.04.

We are 95% confident that the difference in proportions for smokers and nonsmokers with <math alttext="C V D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CVD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the population is between <math alttext="negative 0.01" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and 0.04.

We are 95% confident that the proportion of all smokers with <math alttext="C V D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CVD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is greater than the proportion of all nonsmokers with <math alttext="C V D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CVD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because the interval contains more positive values.

The probability is 0.95 that for all random samples of the same size, the difference in the sample proportions for smokers and nonsmokers with <math alttext="C V D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CVD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be between <math alttext="negative 0.01" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and 0.04.

The probability is 0.95 that there is no difference in the proportions of smokers and nonsmokers with <math alttext="C V D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CVD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because 0 is included in the interval <math alttext="negative 0.01" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.04" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.04</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: We are 95% confident that the difference in proportions for smokers and nonsmokers with <math alttext="C V D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CVD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the population is between <math alttext="negative 0.01" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and 0.04.

topic.text: 6.9: Justifying a Claim Based on a Confidence Interval for a Difference Between Population Proportions
